Ian Badcoe wrote:

>>  Another nice
>>thing is it allows several themes to totally diverge from each other
>>over long periods of time.  In your scheme, it seems possible that
>>because there is no particular guard in place keeping any two
>>individuals from mating, over time you might get more uniformity and
>>convergence.  Not sure about this though, of course it depends on
>>your parameters...but I wonder how things compare.
>>    
>>
>
>I think he does have a partial guard, in that he selects mating pairs with 
>a probability inversely based on their distance.  
>
This /sounds/ like it might have a significant performance overhead - on 
the basis of  requiring more genome comparions than regular discretized 
speciation. I'm coming round to the idea though.


>But he may also be 
>protected by a more natural mechanism, in that when the parents become too 
>disparate, they will become "infertile" with one another and although the 
>system may try to breed them, their offspring will all be of lower fitness 
>than themselves.
>  
>
True, but limited CPU means we can't rely on this sort of approach /too/ 
heavily. All of those bad genomes still need evaluating, and this is CPU 
time that coud be better spent focused on mating genomes we know to be 
reasonably compatible. But I accept that we can adjust the probability 
of mating pairs at a given distance to achieve this with continuous 
speciation - it's not a continuous vs discretized issue.

>A contradictory theory, observed in human "attractiveness" studies, 
>suggests that there is a best degree of diversity to breed with.  When you 
>see a member of the opposite sex who has a different genetic background and 
>who seems very sexy in an exotic way, the theory is that person is just 
>different enough that your sub-conscious tags them as a really promising 
>mate. 
>
This is an intersting point, right now if two genomes are identical then 
they are very likely to get selected as mates - which obviously is not 
going to produce any useful offspring. So a new 'minimum-distance' 
parameter sem like a good idea.

Actually I had another idea today whilst staring at a search that had 
stagnated...

Looking at the list of species in SharpNEAT I could see that all species 
seemed to be stuck in a local peak in the fitness space. Now, when this 
happens species will arrive at the species droppoff age and will be 
dropped from the population. Eventually the number of species will drop 
below the minimum species threshold and so to compensate (this is 
SharpNEAT but I think this is close to other implementations) the genome 
compatibility threshold is lowered and this has the effect of splitting 
some species.

Now this depends on the fitness space, but it seems to me that it's 
likely these new species will get stuck in the same local peaks, 
especially if they are very deep and/or broad, since they are spawned 
off of species that are already stuck. Thus I was thinking that a pool 
of dead species (or a token genome from each, say the species champ) 
could be kept and that we could implement some mechanism for avoiding 
the area of the fitness space represented by these genomes - using the 
genome compatibility function.

I need to think through the specifics on this but it seems to make sense 
because it forces the search into new areas (or it could if implemented 
properly). The problem is how do we ensure we generate new genomes that 
are sufficiently different enough from the dead species to go and 
explore new areas of the search space? The answer may lie within the 
above discussion(s).

>offspring any novel factors, and will even lead to more homozygous 
>deleterious recessives.
